;中国决定从下个月起对重要材料镓和锗实施出口管制中国专家表示，在半导体制造领域，这是一项旨在提高国家安全的有针对性的措施，但也可能带来行业混乱。

;

;此举被广泛视为北京对美国及其盟友强加芯片的报复为了对中国实施限制，中国商务部和海关总署宣布，从 8 月 1 日起，关键金属及相关产品的出口将受到政府批准。

;

;北京此举是利用其准垄断地位低品质的镓。中国占全球稀土金属产量的 90% 以上。

;

;北京吉亚半导体材料有限公司副总经理陈锋表示，该公司年产 60 吨镓，北京已实现“考虑到这种金属对国家安全的战略重要性，这是正确的举动”。与此同时，陈表示，新的出口制度可能会影响中国镓提取商和出口商的业务。

;

;中国在芯片制造金属方面的主导地位受到供应减少的威胁：专家

;

;虽然陈补充道，中国对镓原料的提取具有准垄断地位，中国企业在将稀有金属加工成中间或最终产品时处于劣势。

;

;“镓材料需要纯化并复合成半绝缘材料，但在高纯度材料的生产和成分的稳定性方面，中国与世界领先企业还有相当大的差距。”

;

;他补充道，德国的Freiberger Compound Materials、美国芯片晶圆制造商 AXT 和日本住友电工 (Sumitomo Electric) 是镓加工领域的强大参与者。在中国拥有制造工厂的 AXT 周一表示，将寻求继续从中国出口镓和锗基板产品的许可。

;

;一年前，美国商务部工业与安全局，华盛顿出口管制部门将氧化镓添加到其出口管制清单中，因为含有此类材料的设备可以“显着增加军事潜力”。氧化镓也被列入中国出口管制清单。

;

;根据美国地质调查局的数据，目前全球金属镓储量约为27.93万吨。中国在这些储备中所占比例最大，达到 68%。到2022年，中国的初级低纯镓产量将占全球的98%。

;

;分析师还表示，中国的出口管制可能会推高全球镓及相关产品的价格。券商国金证券发布的一份报告指出，鉴于中国以外的替代品有限，外国供应商可能难以获得足够数量的镓材料。

;

;台湾以赛亚研究公司副总裁 Lucy Chen 表示，此举将“直接影响”下游半导体行业，包括住友、Freiberger和AXT等镓衬底供应商。

;

;“在中国的出口管制下，镓和锗的成本可能会增加，”陈说。她补充说，这可能会对射频产品、功率放大器和通信设备等相关领域产生“连锁反应”。

;

;出口管制的消息导致中国主要金属锗生产公司的股价周二走高，其中投资者押注此举将有利于国内芯片材料行业。

;

;上海上市的国有企业驰宏锌锗股价飙升6.1%。该公司的锗年产能为60吨，该公司周二表示，其红外领域的锗产品出口量“非常小”，预计此次管制对其财务业绩影响不大。

;

;拥有40多年锗开采、加工和开发经验的云南锗业表示，将就最新的出口限制与相关部门“积极沟通”，目前无法评估影响。这家深圳上市公司的股价飙升10%。

;本周早些时候，香港人报告感受到里氏 3.7 级地震的震动，这是第三次地震香港三个月来首次经历如此强烈的地震活动。

;

;香港预报员表示，周一晚间地震的震中位于中国大陆南部地区，一些香港居民短暂感受到了地震的影响。

;

;《华盛顿邮报》与地震学家交谈，详细剖析了读者需要了解的有关香港混凝土丛林中的隆隆声的信息。

;

;派往土耳其地震任务的香港团队被评为首个顶级获胜者获奖

;

;最近的地震报告是什么时候？

;

;根据天文台的数据，周一地震的震中位于广东省河源市西北偏西约23公里（14.2英里）处。;

; p>;

;预报员补充说，香港人在家乡经历了“轻微震动，持续时间为几秒钟”。

;

;这起事件是在香港感受到 4.9 级地震的涟漪之后发生的。 5 月 1 日凌晨，南海发生了地震。

;

;4 月 22 日，香港也发生了另一场地震，震级为 5.3 级。震中位于台湾南部港口城市高雄以西约 190 公里处，距离香港以东约 450 公里。

;

;天文台表示，周一和 4 月份的地震带来的震动感觉就像是“ ”。

;

;但 5 月份地震的震动更加强烈，可能导致悬挂物体摆动，窗户、盘子和门发出嘎嘎声，因为地震发生地距离城市约 300 公里，报告称.

;

;地震通常通过震级和强度来衡量。前者是由震源释放的能量决定的，而后者则记录了某个位置地面震动的程度。

;

;

;

;杨洪峰，研究员中文大学理学院教授表示，香港一般每年会经历六到七次附近地震的震动。

;

;“香港人感受到地震是很常见的，但我们并没有注意到地震的明显增加。今年该地区的地震活动频繁。”他说。

;

;今年到目前为止，该市已经感受到七次不同地震的震动，其中五次发生在广东省。

;

;杨还指出，自1958年河源附近的新丰江水库建成以来，河源附近的地震并不罕见。

;

;“新丰江水库建成三年后，水库大坝附近发生了6.2级地震。 ，“ 他说。 “从那时起，河源就经常发生四级或以下的地震。”

;

;这位在该地区进行研究的学者表示，水库的水可能流入了地球的断层线，润滑它们并可能引发地震。

;

;河源位于香港东北约 167 公里处，在过去 12 个月内报告了 74 起 2 级及以上地震。

;

;南部附近的地震香港报告发生的七次地震中，中国城市也占了三次。

;

;香港小地震让数千人惊醒

;

;

;

;天文台表示香港的地理位置影响了其发生更大规模地震的机会。

;

;“世界上大多数地震发生在地壳板块的边界上。香港位于欧亚板块内，位于横贯日本、台湾和菲律宾的环太平洋地震带上，距太平洋板块最近的边界较远。”

;

;天文台表示，发生地震的可能性远低于日本、台湾、菲律宾和美国西部等地区，并解释说这些地区靠近“地震活跃区”。

;

;中国大学地球物理学家陈彦祖回应了预报员的言论，他说：“香港很少是地震的震中，但我们确实有足够大的断层来产生大规模地震。”

;

;他补充说香港更有可能受到附近广东省等地区发生的地震的影响。

;

;自 1905 年有官方记录以来，香港尚未有任何因地震直接造成的死亡或受伤记录。

;

;唯一一次对香港造成结构性损坏的地震活动是 1918 年农历新年庆祝期间袭击了约 300 公里外的汕头的 7.2 级地震。

;

;损坏包括数处天文台总部的墙壁出现裂缝。

;

;

;

;香港中文大学的杨教授表示，该市“较新的建筑应该能够抵御七级地震”。

;

;地震烈度采用 12 级尺度进行测量，称为修正麦卡利烈度范围。该系统考虑了损失评估和目击者的叙述，结果还取决于某人距离地震震中有多远以及距离地表有多近。

;

;“但是关于老建筑以及它们是否存在的问题仍然存在。能够抵御类似于 1918 年的地震。”他说。

;

;与此同时，Tan 解释说，这座城市通常会经历级别较低的地震活动。

;

;他说：“香港感受到的震动通常为三级或四级，这被认为是轻微的。” “对公众来说，最大的威胁是晃动或摆动的物品，如果掉落，可能会砸到人。”

;

;屋宇署还得出结论，频繁的台风活动意味着该市许多建筑物的建造必须能够承受强风的侵袭。抗风能力强，具有一定的抗震能力。

;

;虽然该类建筑并非专门为抗震而建造，但该部门指出，5至6度的地震仅可能在当地每年发生一次。 72 年，而达到 7 岁的人可能每 475 年才会出现一次。

;香港保安局局长要求通缉活动人士罗冠聪离开美国王国并在该市接受审判，同时指控这位前学生领袖利用年轻抗议者的不幸来谋取私利。

;

;周二，保安局局长邓炳强称这位反对派人物是“现代的”一天前，警方悬赏每人 100 万港元（127,640 美元）。可以提供导致劳和其他七名被指控违反国家安全法的反对派活动人士被捕的信息。

;

;最后所知的逃犯居住在澳大利亚、美国和英国。

;

; >;

;香港悬赏8名国安法嫌疑人，向世界发出“强烈信息”：李

;

;香港国家安全局警司李桂华承认，只有在嫌疑人提出要求的情况下，才有可能逮捕他们

;

;在回应赏金时，罗说：“我所做的都是合法的和平倡导工作。

;

;“我敦促李志锐披露任何证据表明，我与外国势力勾结——我没有接受任何外国资金，也没有受雇于任何外国政府机构。”

;

;“如果他认为[他的所作所为]合法合法，我敦促他返回香港，我们会将证据展示给所有人香港居民出庭。”该部长表示。

;

;据信，在北京于 2020 年 6 月实施国家安全法之前，劳已离开香港前往英国，一年后获得难民身份。

;

; >;

;根据他的个人网站，这位逃亡活动人士还于 2021 年 11 月出版了一本名为《自由》的书，并在英国进行了一系列演讲活动。

;

;提到劳作为知名人士的角色作为2019年反政府骚乱期间的活动人士，唐指责他利用年轻抗议者的不幸来谋取私利。

;

;“你一直表现得像一只胆怯的乌龟，躲着头......沉迷于奢侈的生活。”部长说：“你们在外国煽动年轻人，而你们在香港煽动的年轻人要承担法律后果。”唐重申，市政府将“尽毕生的努力”将这八名嫌疑人绳之以法。正义，警告说，一旦他们不再对外国东道主有用，他们可能会成为“被遗弃的棋子”。

;

;他说，调查人员还在努力追查这些资金并支持通缉逃犯，并补充说，这些赏金将鼓励居民提供有关嫌疑人行踪的任何证据或信息。

;

;部长还强调，向被指控犯有国家安全罪的人提供经济支持是非法的。唐拒绝透露包括袁功义在内的逃犯家属是否会在调查中接受采访。

;

;香港国家安全法：警方悬赏 100 万港元逮捕 8 人

;

;袁是新民党立委容海恩的岳父，后者去年八月买了一份报纸广告，称她已与这位坚定的反对派支持者断绝关系。

;

;这位议员周二在一个广播节目中表示，她已建议她的丈夫、政治分析家袁美昌(Derek Yuen Mi-chang)注意与父亲保持联系的法律和财务影响。

;

;“[袁] 他对国家的看法变得如此极端。物以类聚，人以群分。”她说。

;

;香港国安法：警方悬赏100万港元逮捕8名大律师汤家华

;

;行政会议关键决策机构成员在另一档广播节目中表示，儿子出于孝道向父亲提供经济支持并不违法，因为该行为无意构成国家安全威胁。

;

;北京实施的立法禁止分裂国家、颠覆国家政权、恐怖主义和外国干涉的行为。

;

;唐还承认，警方将八人带回香港的努力是不合理的。可能性不大，因为被指控犯有政治罪的嫌疑人一般不属于国际引渡条约的涵盖范围。

;数十名香港人因涉嫌违反国家规定而被列入警方通缉名单据《华盛顿邮报》获悉，该消息涉及安全法，包括参与众筹活动的人。

;

;周二消息发布的前一天，警方悬赏每人 100 万港元（合 127,700 美元），提供线索以提供线索。逮捕并起诉八名反对派人士。

;

;政府消息人士称，涉嫌触犯国家安全法的城市居民包括被国安警察逮捕后逃保逃亡海外的人。

;

; p>;

;“[被国安警察通缉的人]都是香港居民。他们中的一些人持有外国护照，但拥有该市的居留权，被视为当地公民。”该消息人士称。

;

;他补充说，他们都在该法律生效前后离开了该市2020年，目前大部分在澳大利亚、欧洲和北美。

;

;其中一些人已在全球范围内参与众筹活动，消息人士称，一名活动人士可以在香港筹集数十万美元消息人士警告称，如果支持者的捐款被用于资助诸如煽动分裂国家或颠覆国家政权等犯罪行为，他们可能会被视为违反国家安全法。

;< p>;但他承认警方无能为力阻止此类活动，因为用于收集捐款的银行账户位于香港境外。

;

;他和另一位政府消息人士也承认海外执法机构不太可能机构将帮助抓捕逃犯。

;

;他们解释说，他们可能被视为政治难民，通常不会被国际刑警组织的“红色通缉令”计划列入通缉名单。

;

;国家安全警察已逮捕自该法律于 2020 年 6 月 30 日生效以来，已有 260 名年龄在 15 岁至 90 岁之间的人受到指控。

;

;警方表示，已有 161 人和 5 家公司受到指控。共有79人被定罪。

;

;香港国安法：警方悬赏100万港元逮捕8人

;

;悬赏追捕的8人是前立法会议员弥敦道罗冠忠、郭永亨及许志峰、工会成员蒙兆达、律师任健峰，以及活动人士刘祖迪、郭凤仪及袁恭怡

;

;警方表示，这八人中的七人已呼吁国际社会对香港实施制裁。

;

;另一名消息人士称，这八人之所以被单独挑出来，是因为他们被指控参与严重犯罪。

;

;据称，他们比通缉名单上的其他人更严重地参与了危害国家安全的活动。

;

;但批评者质疑赏金提议的有效性，因为在北京对香港实施国家安全法后，活动人士居住的国家——澳大利亚、英国和美国——暂停了与香港的引渡条约。

;

;他们补充说，涉嫌的政治犯罪通常也被豁免

;

;因国家安全问题被悬赏100万港元的8名香港人是谁？

;

;《邮报》获悉，通缉名单上的其他人包括前立法会议员梁颂恒张颂恒、前英国领事馆雇员郑文杰以及活动人士张君扬和黄台扬。

;

;张是香港高等院校国际事务代表团前发言人，游说支持《香港人权与民主法案》。

;

;另外三人是香港独立运动人士陈家驹、已解散的分裂主义组织“学生本土主义”前成员刘康和美国的香港民主委员会的朱塞缪也被列入名单。

;

;国家安全局总警司李桂华周一呼吁逃犯返回香港自首，这促使逃犯返回香港自首。如果他们被定罪，将保证受到较轻的处罚。

;

;但他补充说，根据国家安全法的规定，他们还必须如实交代自己所涉及的任何罪行，并举报他人犯下的任何罪行.

;

;自2020年开通特别热线以来，该部门已收到超过50万条可能违反国家安全立法的举报。

;

;该热线的设立是为了向公众提供一种通过短信、微信或电子邮件传递信息、照片、音频和视频片段的方式。

;

;警方表示，热线无人接听，未发送回复，也没有收集或向其他任何人透露个人信息.

;中国最高经济规划师听取了私营企业的诉求。它希望在他们继续承受持续斗争和缺乏政策意识的情况下明确这一点。

;

;周一，国家发展和改革委员会 (NDRC) 与一些知名私营企业坐下来“听取意见” ”，同时还讨论了实现疫情后最强劲复苏的实际解决方案。

;

;国家发改委建立了与私营企业联系的新沟通机制，这是一个开始在苦苦挣扎的企业主眼中，这让他们希望北京的政策制定者能够采取更大的措施，包括在七月下旬的政治局重要会议之前实施刺激计划。

;

;“高度可投资”的中国吸引外国人，但又拒绝这样做发改委主任郑善杰在座谈会上表示，发改委将继续向民营企业征求诚实反馈，同时研究有效措施，努力为民营企业发展创造良好环境。

;

;The five participating private firms were construction machinery producer SANY Group, home appliance producer AUX Group, YTO Express, down clothing giant Bosideng and bottled water supplier Nongfu Spring.

;

;The private sector is a crucial driving force for economic growth and social stability, as it accounts for more than 60 per cent of the country's gross domestic product and employs 80 per cent of the urban workforce.

;

;However, it was also hardest hit by the three -year pandemic.

;

;Although China's zero-Covid controls were lifted late last year, it has been difficult for small and medium enterprises to return to their normal production levels in just a few months. Uncertainties endure, and consumption remains suppressed.

;

;According to the China Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (CASME), the index measuring the condition of small and medium-sized firms, most of which are privately run, fell to 88.9 in May from 88.8 in April – higher than the same period in 2022, but lower than the same period in 2021.

;

;The June purchasing managers' index for China's manufacturing sector also showed that the activities of small and medium enterprises remained in contraction territory.

;

;Meanwhile, January-May private investment fell 0.1 per cent, year on year, compared with an 8.4 per cent rise by state-owned enterprises in the same period.

;

;China's state financial sector braces for 'one of the toughest years'

;

;“Private enterprises still need to enhance their confidence,” said Li Zibin, head of CASME.

;

;Li said that removing legal and regulatory barriers and hidden obstacles that affect fair competition and common development among various types of enterprises, and solving the problem of overdue payments for enterprise accounts, “must be done” to boost the confidence of private enterprises.

;

;To further support the private economy, the State Administration for Market Regulation officially launched the second “Month for Services to National Individual Businesses” in late June, with the theme of “Precise Service, Optimised Environment and Improved Quality”.

;

;“Individual businesses have shown clear signs of recovery in various operating indicators currently, but they still face many difficulties in development. To promote the development of individual businesses, it is necessary to improve the level of policy awareness and precision,” according to the market regulator.

; Tue, 04 Jul 2023 20:50:03 +0800 Hong Kong police receive 4 times as many applications in May as a year ago for constables after entry rules eased: security ministerhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3226549/hong-kong-police-receive-4-times-many-applications-may-year-ago-constables-after-entry-rules-eased?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.04 20:40;
;;

;Hong Kong police received four times as many applications in May as a year ago for constables to join the force after entry requirements were relaxed, according to the security minister.

;

;Nearly 500 Hong Kong students in their final year at mainland Chinese universities also signed up for a recruitment scheme to return to the city and join the force after graduation, with 123 of them already completing the selection process.

;

;Secretary for Security Chris Tang Ping-keung revealed the figures on Tuesday as he briefed lawmakers on manpower in the six disciplined services.

;

;Hongkongers taking advantage of relaxed requirements apply to join police

;

;Tang told members of the Legislative Council security panel that staff turnover in the force had improved in recent years.

;

;Police recorded a wastage rate of 2.2 per cent in 2022-23, down from 2.9 per cent the year before and 3.4 per cent in 2020-21.

;

;The rate was the lowest among the disciplinary services, while the Government Flying Service had the highest at 10.1 per cent.

;

;Tang said the revised entry requirements for police had helped attract more applicants, adding: “We are of the view that you will not be prevented from becoming a good and effective cop if you are one inch shorter than that required.”

;

;He was referring to the relaxed rules adopted since May 5, under which previous requirements for applicants to be at least 163cm (5.3 feet) tall and 50kg (110lbs) in weight were removed. Glasses are also allowed to be worn for vision tests under the new procedures.

;

;Applicants who failed their Chinese and English-language subjects in the Diploma of Secondary Education examination will now be given an alternative written test.

;

;Tang told the panel: “In May, the number of applicants for constables increased by four times compared with a year ago. The number of applicants for inspectors also increased by two times.

;

;“We believe this is very much linked to the updated entry requirements.”

;

;But he assured legislators that the quality of officers would not be compromised. “What is important is that when you have completed the training, you will be physically fit enough and will be equipped with sufficient policing knowledge to be a police officer,” he said.

;

;Tang noted the force had received a “positive and favourable” response to a scheme designed to attract Hong Kong students studying on the mainland.

;

;Since its launch last November, the scheme had received a total of 477 applications, according to Tang. As of the end of May, 123 of the students had passed the selection process.

;

;But the force still had 5,911 posts left unfilled in 2022-23, or a vacancy rate of 17.8 per cent, the highest among the disciplined services. The Government Flying Service followed closely with a rate of 16 per cent. The Fire Services Department reported the lowest at 2.5 per cent.

;

;New hiring drive paying off with youngsters, Hong Kong police chief says

;

;Tang said the high vacancy rates were partly because of the decline in the overall labour force.

;

;The disciplined services would also consider using technology to reduce manpower demand, Tang said, citing robots used for nighttime patrols at prisons.

;

;Meanwhile, lawmaker Ambrose Lam San-keung, who represents the legal sector, suggested the force subcontract trivial work, such as handling disputes over water seepage or catching stray pets, to ease officers' workloads.

;

;Hong Kong police ease recruitment criteria to boost flagging interest

;

;Elizabeth Quat, of the Democratic Alliance for Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong, shared Lam's views and said that work combating illegal parking should also be contracted out.

;

;The Legco panel on Tuesday also expressed support for a HK$5.5 billion plan to redevelop the Lai Chi Kok Reception Centre, a maximum security institution under the Correctional Services Department mainly for adult men in custody on remand.

;

;The government plans to submit the funding request to the legislature by the end of the year. If approved, work is expected to be completed in phases from 2025 onwards. The last phase is set to be finished at the end of 2031.

; Tue, 04 Jul 2023 20:20:02 +0800 China’s gallium dominance threatened by dwindling supplies of critical chip-making metal, experts sayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3226545/chinas-gallium-dominance-threatened-dwindling-supplies-critical-chip-making-metal-experts-say?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.04 20:15;
;;

;China produces more than 95 per cent of the world's raw gallium – a critical mineral for making semiconductors – but the situation may not last because of the rapid depletion of natural resources, Chinese experts have warned.

;

;They added that Beijing's recent decision to impose export controls on gallium and germanium, another crucial mineral, could protect China's limited resources and safeguard national security.

;

;Chen Fengying, a researcher with the Beijing-based think tank China Institutes of Contemporary International Relations, said China's export restrictions could be considered a reciprocal measure.

;

;Beijing's new rules came just after the Netherlands announced export controls on advanced chip manufacturing equipment last Friday, following Washington's lead to curb China's chip-making capabilities.

;

;Chen said the protection of finite resources through export controls was a way of protecting national security and interests, the state-owned Global Times reported on Tuesday.

;

;China curbs critical metal exports in retaliation for chip-related sanctions

;

;Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning told a press conference on Tuesday that it was common international practice to impose export restrictions and that China's latest rules did not target any particular country.

;

;“China has always been committed to maintaining the security and stability of the global supply chain and has always implemented fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory export control measures,” Mao said.

;

;Under the restrictions, exporters in China must apply for permission from the Ministry of Commerce and obtain approval from the State Council, China's cabinet, to export certain items.

;

;Both gallium and germanium are key elements in making semiconductors and other electronics. China accounted for more than 95 per cent of the global gallium output and about 60 per cent of germanium production.

;

;Gallium is used in microelectronic components for a diverse range of products. Two of its compounds – gallium arsenide and gallium nitride – are used to manufacture LEDs, solar cells, semiconductors and highly specialised integrated circuits, according to the US Geological Survey (USGS).

;

;Germanium is mainly a by-product of zinc ore processing and is often used in electronics and solar energy applications, as well as in infrared radiation.

;

;China curbs a 'potential bargaining chip' to counter semiconductor ban: experts

;

;According to the USGS, 53 per cent of US gallium imports came from China between 2018 and 2021, followed by Germany and Japan at 13 per cent each.

;

;In 2022, Chinese geologists warned that because of the increasing cost of mining raw gallium and the depletion of resources, China could be forced to recycle gallium from Japan and the US instead of producing it domestically.

;

;If that happens, China's huge resource advantage would reverse and become an advantage for other countries, which would have an adverse impact on China's gallium industry, geologists with the Henan Academy of Geology wrote in the peer-reviewed Chinese journal Mineral Exploration last August.

;

;Although China is the world's largest producer of gallium, it is still at the bottom of the gallium industrial chain because it produces a lot of raw gallium products while relying on Japan and the US for high-end gallium products, according to the authors.

;

;The geologists noted that the demand for gallium largely depended on the demand for high-end downstream products.

;

;“With the expansion of China's business in the global LED market, enhancing the international competitiveness of downstream gallium manufactured products is a must for the development of the gallium industry,” they said.

;

;They suggested better recycling mechanisms and more recycling of gallium-containing ores.

;

;“The demand for gallium is increasing every year. Although China is rich in gallium resources, the recycling system is not perfect and it will constrain China's gallium industry to a sustainable development path,” the study said.

;Armed masked men attacked and seriously injured a prominent female Russian journalist and a lawyer in the Russian region of Chechnya on Tuesday morning after forcing their car to stop, the journalist, her employer and rights groups said.

;

;Yelena Milashina, a well-known journalist for the Novaya Gazeta newspaper, was travelling to the Chechen capital Grozny from the local airport with Alexander Nemov, a lawyer, when they were attacked.

;

;Milashina and Nemov, who had planned to attend a court hearing in the case of a woman they believed was being unjustly persecuted for political reasons, are being transferred to a hospital in a neighbouring region, rights groups said.

;

;“It was a classic kidnapping... They pinned [our driver] down, threw him out of his car, got in, bent our heads down, tied my hands, knelt me down there, and put a gun to my head,” Milashina told Mansur Soltayev, a Chechen human rights official, as she lay in hospital in Grozny before being transferred.

;

;Memorial, a rights group outlawed in Russia, said that Milashina and Nemov had been “brutally kicked, including in the face, threatened with death, had a gun held to their heads, and had their equipment taken away and smashed.”

;

;“While being beaten, they were told: 'You have been warned. Get out of here and don't write anything,'” Memorial said in a statement on Telegram.

;

;A photograph of Milashina, whose newspaper was stripped of its licence in Russia last year, showed her sitting on a hospital bed with her face covered in green dye, her head shaved, and bandages on her left arm and right hand amid reports that several of her fingers had been broken.

;

;Russian anti-war protest journalist faces up to 10 years in prison

;

;There was no immediate comment on the incident from the authorities in Chechnya, a mainly Muslim southern region ruled by Ramzan Kadyrov, a close ally of President Vladimir Putin, who rose to power after two bloody wars that followed the 1991 Soviet break-up.

;

;Some Russian lawmakers and officials in Moscow condemned the attack which they said needed investigating. Mokhmad Akhmadov, a senator from Chechnya, was cited by the state RIA news agency as saying he believed Kadyrov would get to the bottom of things and that he did not think the attack had been sanctioned at an official level.

;

;Milashina has spent years investigating purported human rights abuses in Chechnya, including what she said was the mass arrest and torture of gay men in the region, and had received many threats before, including to her life.

;

;Her employer evacuated her from Russia last year after Kadyrov described her as a terrorist in a social media post and she was assaulted in Chechnya in 2020.

;

;Kadyrov denies rights abuses, saying such allegations are fabricated by ill-wishers trying to discredit Chechnya and its authorities.

;

;The masked men who attacked Milashina on Tuesday shaved her head, broke several of her fingers and covered her head with green dye, according to Memorial, which said she had lost consciousness several times.

;

;Rights group “Team against Torture” said Nemov, the lawyer accompanying her, had been stabbed in the leg and cited him as saying that the masked attackers had used three cars to block the vehicle which he and Milashina had been travelling in.

;

;Milashina and Nemov were in Chechnya to cover the sentencing of Zarema Musayeva, a Chechen woman charged with assaulting a policeman and fraud – charges she denied – in a case critics see as revenge against her sons and husband who are seen as disloyal by Kadyrov and have fled the country.

;

;A Chechen court on Tuesday found Musayeva guilty and sentenced her to five-and-a-half years in a penal colony.

;

;A Russian court last year stripped Novaya Gazeta, led by Dmitry Muratov, a Nobel Peace laureate, of its media licence, a move Muratov said was politically-motivated.
